instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2390: What is 820-2390? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on (bad <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>)
threads.message:
Im still pretty new to board level repair, I have watched around 20+ hours of Louis's videos. So im catching on. But I still have a lot to learn. I do have a schematic and board view for this logic board.

-Looked over the board really well for liquid damage none was found.
-Tried a new keyboard/power button still no fan spin.
- I do get Green light on charger
- Tried another charger

At this point I started measuring power rails started with the main 3 Louis talks about.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> -  8.4v  ( I thought this was suppose to 12v, the schematic says its suppose to be 6v. im a little confused on this)

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.44v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - missing 0.0v

If you can point be toward the next step that would be great.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on (bad <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>)
threads.message: Voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>? If it is not 1V or so, change <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> to a normal size 330uF.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2390</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not powering on (bad <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>)
threads.message:
The voltage was 0.3v, I changed that cap measuring 1.1v fixed the issue. Thanks Duke. 
I just watched one of the videos from Louis last night that he did this is exact same process. Very helpful stuff.
